source.author: Ross, J.H.
source.title: Hovea
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Ross, J.H. (1996). Hovea. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Subshrub with slender, trailing, straggling or weakly erect stems; young stems and lower surfaces of leaves clothed with long appressed antrorse hairs; leaves dimorphic, the lowermost elliptic or ovate, upper ones more or less oblong
More or less upright shrub or small tree; indumentum of young stems and lower surface of the leaves including at least some spreading hairs; leaves not conspicuously dimorphic
Leaf-lamina mostly 3–11.5 cm long, 0.7–2 cm wide; upper surface smooth, glossy, ± flat either side of the depressed midrib; pedicels 5–9.5 mm long; bract inserted 4.5–8 mm below bracteoles

Leaf-lamina mostly 1–8 cm long, 0.4–1.2 cm wide; upper surface smooth or distinctly scabrous, usually arched up either side of the depressed midrib; pedicels to 4 mm long; bract inserted less than 4 mm below the bracteoles
Compact, spreading shrub to 0.5 m high, the stems ascending or the outer ones somewhat decumbent, sometimes rooting at nodes; bracteoles obtuse apically; alps and subalps above 1200 m
Shrub or small tree, usually over 0.5 m high, stems ascending; bracteoles usually acute or acuminate apically; lowland to montane areas below 1200 m

Standard (including basal claw) 11.5–17 mm long, usually longer than wide; keel petals consistently as long as or longer than wings; stamen-filaments 8.5–16 mm long; bracts and bracteoles 1.5–3.5 mm wide, obovate-oblong, oblong, obovate or broadly ovate, sometimes cymbiform; apparently confined to upper Genoa River

Standard (including basal claw) 7–11 mm long, invariably wider than long; keel petals consistently shorter than wings; stamen-filaments up to 6 mm long; bracts and bracteoles usually less than 1.5 mm wide, narrow-ovate, acute to acuminate apically; widespread
Indumentum of long spreading hairs projecting more than 0.8 mm beyond underlying appressed hair, obscuring outline of floral parts; stipules more than 2 mm long
Indumentum usually lacking long spreading hairs, or if present, projecting less than 0.8 mm beyond underlying hair; stipules mostly less than 2 mm long
Upper surface of leaves smooth; bracts 3–5 mm long, more than 2 mm wide, inserted immediately below bracteoles; calyx 4.5–7 mm long
Upper surface of leaves scabrid, sometimes minutely so; bracts 1–4(–5.5) mm long, usually less than 2 mm wide, inserted up to 2 mm below bracteoles; calyx 3–5(–5.5) mm long
Margins of leaves revolute, lower surface completely obscured by a close tan indumentum, lacking longer spreading hairs; bracteoles up to 2 mm long; standard less than 7 mm long; Grampians

Margins of leaves recurved to revolute, lower surface of leaves usually at least partially visible, or with scattered longer spreading hairs overtopping the underlying appressed hairs; bracteoles up to 5.5 mm long; standard more than 7 mm long; widespread
